element.name: EListError
element.short: Exception raised when an error occurs in lists handling.

descr.p: If an error occurs in one of the or methods, then a EListError exception is raised. This can occur in one of the following cases:

ol.li: There is not enough memory to expand the list.
The list tried to grow beyond its maximal capacity.
An attempt was made to reduce the capacity of the list below the current element count.
An attempt was made to set the list count to a negative value.
A non-existent element of the list was referenced. (i.e. the list index was out of bounds)
An attempt was made to move an item to a position outside the list's bounds.

element.name: TList
element.short: Class to manage collections of pointers.

descr.p: TList is a class that can be used to manage collections of pointers. It introduces methods and properties to store the pointers, search in the list of pointers, sort them. It manages its memory by itself, no intervention for that is needed. It has an event notification mechanism which allows to notify of list changes. This slows down some of TList mechanisms, and if no notification is used, may be used instead.
To manage collections of strings, it is better to use a descendent such as . To manage general objects, a class exists, from which a descendent can be made to manage collections of various kinds.

element.name: TList.Create
element.short: Class to manage collections of pointers.

descr.p: TList.Create creates a new instance of TList. It clears the list and prepares it for use.

element.name: TList.Destroy
element.short: Destroys the list and releases the memory used to store the list elements.
element.descr: Destroy destroys the list and releases the memory used to store the list elements. The elements themselves are in no way touched, i.e. any meomory they point to must be explicitly released before calling the destructor.

element.name: TList.Add
element.short: Adds a new pointer to the list.

descr.p: Add adds a new pointer to the list after the last pointer (i.e. at position Count, thus increasing the item count with 1. If the list is at full capacity, the capacity of the list is expanded, using the Grow method.
To insert a pointer at a certain position in the list, use the Insert method instead.

element.name: TList.Clear
element.short: Clears the pointer list.
element.descr: Clear removes all pointers from the list, and sets the capacity to 0, thus freeing any memory allocated to maintain the list.

element.name: TList.Delete
element.short: Removes a pointer from the list.

descr.p: Delete removes the pointer at position Index from the list, shifting all following pointers one position up (or to the left).
The memory the pointer is pointing to is not deallocated.

element.name: TList.Error
element.short: Raises an exception.
element.descr: Error raises an exception, with a message formatted with Msg and Data.

element.name: TList.Exchange
element.short: Exchanges two pointers in the list.
element.descr: Exchange exchanges the pointers at positions Index1 and Index2. Both pointers must be withing the current range of the list, or an exception will be raised.

element.name: TList.Expand
element.short: Increases the capacity of the list if needed.

descr.p: Expand increases the capacity of the list if the current element count matches the current list capacity.
The capacity is increased according to the following algorithm:

ol.li: If the capacity is less than 3, the capacity is increased with 4.
If the capacity is larger than 3 and less than 8, the capacity is increased with 8.
If the capacity is larger than 8, the capacity is increased with 16.

descr.p: The return value is Self.

element.name: TList.First
element.short: Returns the first non-nil pointer in the list.

descr.p: First returns the value of the first non-nil pointer in the list.
If there are no pointers in the list or all pointers equal Nil, then Nil is returned.

element.name: TList.IndexOf
element.short: Returns the index of a given pointer.

descr.p: IndexOf searches for the pointer Item in the list of pointers, and returns the index of the pointer, if found.
If no pointer with the value Item was found, -1 is returned.

element.name: TList.Insert
element.short: Inserts a new pointer in the list at a given position.

descr.p: Insert inserts pointer Item at position Index in the list. All pointers starting from Index are shifted to the right.
If Index is not a valid position, then a exception is raised.

element.name: TList.Insert.Item
element.short: Pointer to be inserted.

element.name: TList.Insert.Index
element.short: Position where to insert

element.name: TList.Last
element.short: Returns the last non-nil pointer in the list.

descr.p: Last returns the value of the last non-nil pointer in the list.
If there are no pointers in the list or all pointers equal Nil, then Nil is returned.

element.name: TList.Move
element.short: Moves a pointer from one position in the list to another.

descr.p: Move moves the pointer at position CurIndex to position NewIndex. This is done by storing the value at position CurIndex, deleting the pointer at position CurIndex, and reinserting the value at position NewIndex
If CurIndex or Newindex are not inside the valid range of indices, an exception is raised.

element.name: TList.Remove
element.short: Removes a value from the list.
element.descr: Remove searches Item in the list, and, if it finds it, deletes the item from the list. Only the first occurrence of Item is removed.

element.name: TList.Pack
element.short: Removes Nil pointers from the list and frees unused memory.
element.descr:
Pack removes all nil pointers from the list. The capacity of the list is then set to the number of pointers in the list.
This method can be used to free unused memory if the list has grown to very large sizes and has a lot of unneeded nil pointers in it.

element.name: TList.Sort
element.short: Sorts the pointers in the list.

ul.li: If the result of this function is negative, the first pointer is assumed to be 'less' than the second and will be moved before the second in the list.
If the function result is positive, the first pointer is assumed to be 'greater than' the second and will be moved after the second in the list.
if the function result is zero, the pointers are assumed to be 'equal' and no moving will take place.

descr.p: The sort is done using a quicksort algorithm.

element.name: TList.Capacity
element.short: Current capacity (i.e. number of pointers that can be stored) of the list.

descr.p: Capacity contains the number of pointers the list can store before it starts to grow.

If a new pointer is added to the list using add or insert, and there is not enough memory to store the new pointer, then the list will try to allocate more memory to store the new pointer. Since this is a time consuming operation, it is important that this operation be performed as little as possible. If it is known how many pointers there will be before filling the list, it is a good idea to set the capacity first before filling. This ensures that the list doesn't need to grow, and will speed up filling the list.

element.name: Tlist.Count
element.short: Current number of pointers in the list.
element.descr: Count is the current number of (possibly Nil) pointers in the list. Since the list is zero-based, the index of the largest pointer is Count-1.

element.name: TList.Items
element.short: Probides access to the pointers in the list.

descr.p: Items is used to access the pointers in the list. It is the default property of the TList class, so it can be omitted.
The list is zero-based, so Index must be in the range 0 to Count-1.

element.name: TList.List
element.short: Memory array where pointers are stored.
element.descr: List points to the memory space where the pointers are stored. This can be used to quickly copy the list of pinters to another location.

element.name: TBits
element.short: Class to store collections of bits (binary values that can be 0 or 1)

descr.p: TBits can be used to store collections of bits in an indexed array. This is especially useful for storing collections of booleans: Normally the size of a boolean is the size of the smallest enumerated type, i.e. 1 byte. Since a bit can take 2 values it can be used to store a boolean as well. Since TBits can store 8 bits in a byte, it takes 8 times less space to store an array of booleans in a TBits class then it would take to stoe them in a conventional array.
TBits introduces methods to store and retrieve bit values, apply masks, and search for bits.

element.name: TBits.Create
element.short: Creates a new bits collection.

descr.p: Create creates a new bit collection with initial size TheSize. The size of the collection can be changed later on.
All bits are initially set to zero.

element.name: TBits.Destroy
element.short: Destroys a bit collection

descr.p: Destroy destroys a previously created bit collection and releases all memory used to store the bit collection.
Destroy should never be called directly, Free should be used instead.

element.errors: None.

element.short: Returns the number of records used to store the bits.
element.descr: GetFSize returns the number of records used to store the current number of bits.
element.errors: None.

element.short: Turn a particular bit on.
element.descr: SetOn turns on the bit at position bit, i.e. sets it to 1. If bit is at a position bigger than the current size, the collection is expanded to the required size using Grow.
element.errors: If bit is larger than the maximum allowed bits array size or is negative, an exception is raised.

element.name: TBits.clear
element.short: Clears a particular bit.
element.descr: Clear clears the bit at position bit. If the array If bit is at a position bigger than the current size, the collection is expanded to the required size using Grow.
element.errors: If bit is larger than the maximum allowed bits array size or is negative, an exception is raised.

element.name: TBits.clearall
element.short: Clears all bits in the array.
element.descr: ClearAll clears all bits in the array, i.e. sets them to zero. ClearAll works faster than clearing all individual bits, since it uses the packed nature of the bits.
element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.andbits
element.short: Performs an and operation on the bits.
element.descr: andbits performs an and operation on the bits in the array with the bits of array BitSet. If BitSet contains less bits than the current array, then all bits which have no counterpart in BitSet are cleared.
element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.orbits
element.short: Performs an or operation on the bits.

descr.p: andbits performs an or operation on the bits in the array with the bits of array BitSet.
If BitSet contains less bits than the current array, then all bits which have no counterpart in BitSet are left untouched.
If the current array contains less bits than BitSet then it is grown to the size of BitSet before the or operation is performed.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.xorbits
element.short: Performs a xor operation on the bits.

descr.p: XorBits performs a xor operation on the bits in the array with the bits of array BitSet.
If BitSet contains less bits than the current array, then all bits which have no counterpart in BitSet are left untouched.
If the current array contains less bits than BitSet then it is grown to the size of BitSet before the xor operation is performed.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.notbits
element.short: Performs a not operation on the bits.

descr.p: NotBits performs a not operation on the bits in the array with the bits of array Bitset.
If BitSet contains less bits than the current array, then all bits which have no counterpart in BitSet are left untouched.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.get
element.short: Retrieve the value of a particular bit
element.descr: Get returns True if the bit at position bit is set, or False if it is not set.
element.errors: If bit is not a valid bit index then an exception is raised.

element.name: TBits.grow
element.short: Expands the bits array to the requested size.
element.descr: Grow expands the bit array so it can at least contain nbit bits. If nbit is less than the current size, nothing happens.
element.errors: If there is not enough memory to complete the operation, then an is raised.

element.name: TBits.equals
element.short: Determines whether the bits of 2 arrays are equal.

descr.p: equals returns True if all the bits in BitSet are the same as the ones in the current BitSet; if not, False is returned.
If the sizes of the two BitSets are different, the arrays are still reported equal when all the bits in the larger set, which are not present in the smaller set, are zero.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.SetIndex
element.short: Sets the start position for FindNextBit and FindPrevBit

descr.p: SetIndex sets the search start position forFindNextBit and FindPrevBit to Index. This means that these calls will start searching from position Index.
This mechanism provides an alternative to FindFirstBit which can also be used to position for the FindNextBit and FindPrevBit calls.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.FindFirstBit
element.short: Find first bit with a particular value

descr.p: FindFirstBit searches for the first bit with value State. It returns the position of this bit, or -1 if no such bit was found.

The search starts at position 0 in the array. If the first search returned a positive result, the found position is saved, and the FindNextBit and FindPrevBit will use this position to resume the search. To start a search from a certain position, the start position can be set with the SetIndex instead.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.FindNextBit
element.short: Searches the next bit with a particular value.

descr.p: FindNextBit resumes a previously started search. It searches for the next bit with the value specified in the FindFirstBit. The search is done towards the end of the array and starts at the position last reported by one of the Find calls or at the position set with SetIndex.
If another bit with the same value is found, its position is returned. If no more bits with the same value are present in the array, -1 is returned.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.FindPrevBit
element.short: Searches the previous bit with a particular value.

descr.p: FindPrevBit resumes a previously started search. It searches for the previous bit with the value specified in the FindFirstBit. The search is done towards the beginning of the array and starts at the position last reported by one of the Find calls or at the position set with SetIndex.
If another bit with the same value is found, its position is returned. If no more bits with the same value are present in the array, -1 is returned.

element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.OpenBit
element.short: Returns the position of the first bit that is set to False.
element.descr: OpenBit returns the position of the first bit whose value is 0 (False), or -1 if no open bit was found. This call is equivalent to FindFirstBit(False), except that it doesn't set the position for the next searches.
element.errors: None.

element.name: TBits.Bits
element.short: Access to all bits in the array.
element.descr: Bits allows indexed access to all of the bits in the array. It gives True if the bit is 1, False otherwise; Assigning to this property will set, respectively clear the bit.
element.errors: If an index is specified which is out of the allowed range then an exception is raised.

element.name: TBits.Size
element.short: Current size of the array of bits.
element.descr: Size is the current size of the bit array. Setting this property will adjust the size; this is equivalent to calling Grow(Value-1)
element.errors: If an invalid size (negative or too large) is specified, a exception is raised.

element.name: TPersistent
element.short: Base class for streaming system and persistent properties.

descr.p: TPersistent is the basic class for the streaming system. Since it is compiled in the {$M+} state, the compiler generates RTTI (Run-Time Type Information) for it and all classes that descend from it. This information can be used to stream all properties of classes.
It also introduces functionality to assign the contents of 2 classes to each other.

element.name: TPersistent.AssignError
element.short: Raises an EConvertError when an error occurs during assignment.
element.descr: AssignError raises an EConvertError exception with the classnames of the Source and destination classes. It is used when two incompatible classes are assigned to each other.

element.name: TPersistent.AssignTo
element.short: Generic assignment function.

descr.p: AssignTo is the generic function to assign the class' contents to another class. This method must be overridden by descendent classes to actually assign the content of the source instance to the destination instance.

The implementation of Assignto raises an EConvertError exception. This is done for the following reason: If the source class doesn't know how to assign itself to the destination class (using AssignTo), the destination class may know how get the data from the source class (using Assign). If all descendent methods are implemented correctly, then if neither of the two classes knows how to assign their contents to each other, execution will end up at , which will simply execute
If neither of the classes knows how to assign to/from each other, then execution will end up at the TPersistent implementation of AssignTo, and an exception will be raised.

element.name: TPersistent.DefineProperties
element.short: Declare non-published properties that need to be streamed.

descr.p: DefineProperties must be overridden by descendent classes to indicate to the streaming system which non-published properties must also be streamed.

The streaming systems stores only published properties in the stream. Sometimes it is necessary to store additional data in the stream, data which is not published. This can be done by overriding the DefineProperties method. The Filer object is the class that is responsible for writing all properties to the stream.
To define new properties, two methods of the class should be used:

ol.li: DefineProperty, to define a property which can be represented as text.
DefineProperty, to define a property which contains binary data.

descr.p: On order for the streaming to work correctly, a call to the inherited DefineProperties is also needed, so ancestor objects also get the possibility to read or write their private data to the stream. Failure to call the inherited method will result in component properties not being streamed correctly.

element.name: TPersistent.GetOwner
element.short: Returns the owner of the component.
element.descr: GetOwner returns the owning component of the classes instane. The TPersistent implementation of GetOwner returns Nil. overrides this method.

element.name: TPersistent.Destroy
element.short: Destroys the TPersistent instance.
element.descr: Destroy disposes of the persistent object. This method should never be called directly. Instead the Free method should be used.

element.name: TPersistent.Assign
element.short: Assign the contents of one class to another.

descr.p: Assign copies the contents of Source to Self, if the classes of the destination and source classes are compatible.

The TPersistent implementation of Assign does nothing but calling the AssignTo method of source. This means that if the destination class does not know how to assign the contents of the source class, the source class instance is asked to assign itself to the destination class. This means that it is necessary to implement only one of the two methods so that two classes can be assiged to one another.

remark.p: In general, a statement of the form
(where Destination and Source are classes) does not achieve the same as a statement of the form
After the former statement, both Source and Destination will point to the same object. The latter statemtent will copy the contents of the Source class to the Destination class.

element.name: TPersistent.GetNamePath
element.short: Returns a string that can be used to identify the class instance.

descr.p: GetNamePath returns a string that can be used to identify the class instance. This can be used to display a name for this instance in a Object designer.
GetNamePath constructs a name by recursively prepending the Classname of the Owner instance to the Classname of this instance, separated by a dot.

element.name: TPersistentClass
element.short: Class reference type for .
element.descr: TPersistentClass is the class reference type for the class.

element.name: TCollectionItem
element.short: Basic object that is managed by a class.

descr.p: TCollectionItem and form a pair of base classes that manage a collection of named objects. The TCollectionItem is the named object that is managed, it represents one item in the collection. An item in the collection is represented by two properties: , and .

A TCollectionItem object is never created directly. To manage a set of named items, it is necessary to make a descendent of TCollectionItem to which needed properties and methods are added. This descendant can then be managed with a class. The managing collection will create and destroy it's items by itself, it should therefore never be necessary to create TCollectionItem descendents manually.

element.name: TCollectionItem.Changed
element.short: Method to notify the managing collection that the name or index of this item has changed.
element.descr: This method is called when the is set or when the is changed.

element.name: TCollectionItem.GetNamePath
element.short: Returns the namepath of this collection item.
element.descr: GetNamePath overrides the method to return the name of the managing collection and appends its property.

element.name: TCollectionItem.GetOwner
element.short: Returns the managing collection.
element.descr: TCollectionItem overrides to and returns the that manages it.

element.name: TCollectionItem.GetDisplayName
element.short: Returns the of the collectionitem

descr.p: GetDisplayName returns the value of the property. By default, this is the classname of the actual TCollectionItem descendant.
Descendants of TCollectionItem can and should override this method to return a more meaningful value.

element.name: TCollectionItem.SetIndex
element.short: Write method for the property.
element.descr: SetIndex implements the write handler for the property. It requests the managing collection to move this item to the desired index value.

element.name: TCollectionItem.SetDisplayName
element.short: Write method for the property

descr.p: SetDisplayName is the write method for the property. It does nothing but notifying the managing collection that the displayname has changed. It does NOT store the actual Value.
Descendants of TCollectionItem should override this method to store the actual displayname if this is required.

element.name: TCollectionItem.Create
element.short: Creates a new instance of this collection item.
element.descr: Create instantiates a new item in a . It is called by the function and should under normal circumstances never be called directly. called

element.name: TCollectionItem.Destroy
element.short: Destroyes this collection item.

descr.p: Destroy removes the item from the managing collection and Destroys the item instance.
This is the only way to remove items from a collection;

element.name: TCollectionItem.Collection
element.short: Pointer to the collection managing this item.
element.descr: Collection points to the collection managing this item. This property can be set to point to a new collection. If this is done, the old collection will be notified that the item should no longer be managed, and the new collection is notified that it should manage this item as well.

element.name: TCollectionItem.ID
element.short: Initial index of this item.

descr.p: ID is the initial value of ; it doesn't change after the index changes. It can be used to uniquely identify the item. The ID property doesn't change as items are added and removed from the collection.

While the property forms a continuous series, ID does not. If items are removed from the collection, their ID is not used again, leaving gaps. Only when the collection is initialiiy created, the ID and Index properties will be equal.

element.name: TCollectionItem.Index
element.short: Index of the item in its managing collection property.

descr.p: Index is the current index of the item in its managing collection's property. This property may change as items are added and removed from the collection.
The index of an item is zero-based, i.e. the first item has index zero. The last item has index Count-1 where Count is the number of items in the collection.
The Index property of the items in a collection form a continuous series ranging from 0 to Count-1. The property does not form a continuous series, but can also be used to identify an item.

element.name: TCollectionItem.DisplayName
element.short: Name of the item, displayed in the object inspector.

descr.p: DisplayName contains the name of this item as shown in the object inspector. For TCollectionItem this returns always the class name of the managing collection, followed by the index of the item.

TCollectionItem does not implement any functionality to store the DisplayName property. The property can be set, but this will have no effect other than that the managing collection is notified of a change. The actual displayname will remain unchanged. To store the DisplayName property,TCollectionItem descendants should override the and to add storage functionality.

element.name: TCollectionItemClass
element.short: Class reference for .
element.descr: TCollectionItemClass is used by the property of to identify the descendent class of which should be created and managed.

element.name: TCollection
element.short: Base class to manage collections of named objects.

descr.p: TCollection implements functionality to manage a collection of named objects. Each of these objects needs to be a descendent of the class. Exactly which type of object is managed can be seen from the property.
Normally, no TCollection is created directly. Instead, a descendents of TCollection and are created as a pair.

element.name: TCollection.GetAttrCount
element.short: Returns the count of attributes associated with each item.

descr.p: GetAttrCount returns 0 in the TCollection implementation. It can be used to determine the number of attributes associated with each collection item. Descendent objects should override this method to return the number of attributes.
This method is provided for compatibility with Delphi only and is not used in Free Pascal.

element.name: TCollection.GetAttr
element.short: Returns an attribute of the collection.

descr.p: This method is provided for compatibility with Delphi only and is not used in Free Pascal.

element.name: TCollection.GetItemAttr
element.short: Returns the attributes of an item.

descr.p: This method is provided for compatibility with Delphi only and is not used in Free Pascal.

element.name: TCollection.GetNamePath
element.short: Overrides to return a proper pathname.

descr.p: GetNamePath returns the name path for this collection. If the following conditions are satisfied:

ol.li: There is an owner object.
The owner object returns a non-empty name path.
The property is not empty

descr.p: collection has an owner and the owning object has a name, then the function returns the owner name, followed by the propname. If one of the conditions is not satisfied, then the classname is returned.

element.name: TCollection.Changed
element.short: Procedure called if an item is added to or removed from the collection.
element.descr: Changed is called if a change takes place in the collection managed by the class. If the update count ghas reached zero, it calls with a nil argument.

element.name: TCollection.GetItem
element.short: Read handler for the property.
element.descr: GetItem is the read handler for the property. It returns the Index-th element from the list of objects.
element.errors: If Index is outside the allowed range, then an exception is raised.

element.name: TCollection.SetItem
element.short: Write handler for the property.
element.descr: SetItem implements the write handler for the property. It assignes Value to the Index-th element in the array. For this to work properly, the method of the Item must work correctly.
element.errors: If Index is outside the allowed range, then an exception is raised.

element.name: TCollection.SetItemName
element.short: Virtual method to set the name of the specified item

element.name: TCollection.SetPropName
element.short: Write handler for the property
element.descr: SetPropName must be overridden by descendent objects to set the property to a suitable value. By default, SetPropName sets the PropName property to empty.

element.name: TCollection.Update
element.short: Hander called when an item in the collection has changed.

descr.p: Update is called in the following cases:

ol.li: An item is added to or removed from the collection.
An item is moved in the list, i.e. its property changes.
An item's property changes.

descr.p: Descendent classes can override this method to perform additional actions when the collection changes. The Item parameter indicates the item that was changed. This can be Nil

element.name: TCollection.PropName
element.short: Name of the property that this collection represents.
element.descr: PropName indicates the name of the property that this collection is supposed to represent. By default, this is the empty string. Descendents can override this property to return the name of the property that is represented by this collection.

element.name: TCollection.Create
element.short: Creates a new collection.
element.descr: Create instantiates a new instance of the TCollection class which will manage objects of class AItemClass. It creates the list used to hold all objects, and stores the AItemClass for the adding of new objects to the collection.

element.name: TCollection.Destroy
element.short: Destroys the collection and frees all the objects it manages.

descr.p: Destroy first clears the collection, and then frees all memory allocated to this instance.
Don't call Destroy directly, call Free instead.

element.name: TCollection.Add
element.short: Creates and adds a new item to the collection.
element.descr: Add instantiates a new item of class and adds it to the list. The newly created object is returned.

element.name: TCollection.Assign
element.short: Assigns one collection to another.

descr.p: Assign assigns the contents of one collection to another. It does this by clearing the items list, and adding as much elements as there are in the Source collection; it assigns to each created element the contents of it's counterpart in the Source element.
Two collections cannot be assigned to each other if instances of the ItemClass classes cannot be assigned to each other.

element.errors: If the objects in the collections cannot be assigned to one another, then an EConvertError is raised.

element.name: TCollection.BeginUpdate
element.short: Start an update batch.

descr.p: BeginUpdate is called at the beginning of a batch update. It raises the update count with 1.

Call BeginUpdate at the beginning of a series of operations that will change the state of the collection. This will avoid the call to for each operation. At the end of the operations, a corresponding call to EndUpdate must be made. It is best to do this in the context of a Try ... finally block:
This insures that the number of calls to BeginUpdate always matches the number of calls to , even in case of an exception.

element.name: TCollection.Clear
element.short: Removes all items from the collection.
element.descr: Clear will clear the collection, i.e. each item in the collection is destroyed and removed from memory. After a call to Clear, Count is zero.

element.name: TCollection.EndUpdate
element.short: Ends an update batch.
element.descr: EndUpdate signals the end of a series of operations that change the state of the collection, possibly triggering an update event. It does this by decreasing the update count with 1 and calling it should always be used in conjunction with , preferably in the Finally section of a Try ... Finally block.

element.name: TCollection.FindItemID
element.short: Searches for an Item in the collection, based on its property.

descr.p: FindItemID searches through the collection for the item that has a value of ID for its property, and returns the found item. If no such item is found in the collection, Nil is returned.
The routine performs a linear search, so this can be slow on very large collections.

element.name: TCollection.Count
element.short: Number of items in the collection.

descr.p: Count contains the number of items in the collection.
descr.remark: The items in the collection are identified by their property, which is a zero-based index, meaning that it can take values between 0 and Count.

element.name: TCollection.ItemClass
element.short: Class pointer for each item in the collection.
element.descr: ItemClass is the class pointer with which each new item in the collection is created. It is the value that was passed to the collection's constructor when it was created, and does not change during the lifetime of the collection.

element.name: TCollection.Items
element.short: Indexed array of items in the collection.

descr.p: Items provides indexed access to the items in the collection. Since the array is zero-based, Index should be an integer between 0 and Count-1.

It is possible to set or retrieve an element in the array. When setting an element of the array, the object that is assigned should be compatible with the class of the objects in the collection, as given by the property.
Adding an element to the array can be done with the method. The array can be cleared with the method. Removing an element of the array should be done by freeing that element.

element.name: TStrings
element.short: Class to manage arrays or collections of strings

descr.p: TStrings implements an abstract class to manage an array of strings. It introduces methods to set and retrieve strings in the array, searching for a particular string, concatenating the strings and so on. It also allows an arbitrary object to be associated with each string.
It also introduces methods to manage a series of name=value settings, as found in many configuration files.

An instance of TStrings is never created directly, instead a descendent class such as should be created. This is because TStrings is an abstract class which does not implement all methods; TStrings also doesn't store any strings, this is the functionality introduced in descendents such as .

element.name: TStrings.DefineProperties
element.short: Method to stream the contents of the string collection
element.descr: DefineProperties allows the contents of the string collection to be streamed. As such, it overrides

element.name: TStrings.Error
element.short: Raises an exception.

descr.p: Error raises an exception. It passes Msg as a format with Data as the only argument.
This method can be used by descendent objects to raise an error.

element.name: TStrings.Get
element.short: Abstract read handler for the property.

descr.p: Get is the abstract read handler for the property. This is an abstract method, hence it is not implemented in TStrings.

Descendent classes, such as must override this method and implement a routine that retrieves the Index-th string in the list. Index should have a value between 0 and Count-1, in all other cases an error should be raised using .

element.name: TStrings.GetCapacity
element.short: Abstract Read handler for the property.

descr.p: GetCapacity is the read handler for the property. The implementation in TStrings will return 0.
Descendent classes can override this method. It should return the current number of strings that can be held by the stringlist before it attempts to expand it's storage space.

element.name: TStrings.GetCount
element.short: Abstract read handler for the property.

descr.p: GetCount is the abstract read handler for the property. This is an abstract method, hence it is not implemented in TStrings.
Descendent classes must override this method. It should return the current number of strings in the list. (empty strings included).

element.name: TStrings.GetObject
element.short: Abstract read handler for the property.

descr.p: GetObject is the read handler for the property. The TStrings implementation of this method ignores the Index argument and simply returns Nil.

Descendent classes that should support object storage should override this method and return the object associated to the Index-th string in the list. Index should have a value between 0 and Count-1. If Index is outside the allowed range, an error should be raised using .

element.name: TStrings.GetTextStr
element.short: Read handler for the property.

descr.p: GetTextStr is the read handler for the property. It simply concatenates all strings in the list with a linefeed between them, and returns the resulting string.
Descendent classes may override this method to implement an efficienter algorithm which is more suitable to their storage method.

element.name: TStrings.Put
element.short: Write handler for the property.

descr.p: Put is the write handler for the property. It does this by saving the object associated to the Index-th string, deleting the Index-th string, and inserting S and the saved object at position Index with
Descendent classes may wish to override Put to implement a more efficient method.

element.name: TStrings.PutObject
element.short: Write handler for the property.

descr.p: PutObject is the write handler for the property. The TStrings implementation of PutObject does nothing.

Descendent objects that should support Object storage must override this method to store the AObject so that it is associated with the Index-th string in the list. Index should have a value between 0 and Count-1. If the value of Index is out of range, an error should be raised using .

element.name: TStrings.SetCapacity
element.short: Write handler for the property.

descr.p: SetCapacity is the write handler for the property. The TStrings implementation of SetCapacity does nothing.

Descendent classes can override this method to set the current capacity of the stringlist to NewCapacity. The capacity is the number of strings the list can hold before it tries to expand its storage space. NewCapacity should be no less than Count.

element.name: TStrings.SetTextStr
element.short: Write handler for the property.

descr.p: SetTextStr is the write method for the property. It does nothing other than calling .
Descendent classes may override this method to implement a more efficient algoritm that fits their storage method better.

element.name: TStrings.SetUpdateState
element.short: Sets the update state.

descr.p: SetUpdateState sets the update state to Updating. The TStrings implementation of SetUpdateState does nothing.

Descendent objects may override this method to implement optimizations. If Updating is True then the list of strings is about to be updated (possibly many times). If it is False no more updates will take place till the next SetUpdateState call.

element.name: TStrings.Destroy
element.short: Frees all strings and objects, and removes the list from memory.
element.descr: Destroy is the destructor of TStrings it does nothing except calling the inherited destructor.

element.name: TStrings.Add
element.short: Add a string to the list
element.descr: Add adds S at the end of the list and returns the index of S in the list (which should equal

element.name: TStrings.AddObject
element.short: Add a string and associated object to the list.

descr.p: AddObject adds S to the list of strings, and associates AObject with it. It returns the index of S.
descr.remark: An object added to the list is not automatically destroyed by the list of the list is destroyed or the string it is associated with is deleted. It is the responsibility of the application to destroy any objects associated with strings.

element.name: TStrings.Append
element.short: Add a string to the list.
element.descr: Append does the same as , only it does not return the index of the inserted string.

element.name: TStrings.AddStrings
element.short: Add contents of another stringlist to this list.
element.descr: AddStrings adds the contents of TheStrings to the stringlist. Any associated objects are added as well.

element.name: TStrings.Assign
element.short: Assign the contents of another stringlist to this one.
element.descr: Assign replaces the contents of the stringlist with the contents of Source if Source is also of type TStrings. Any associated objects are copied as well.

element.name: TStrings.BeginUpdate
element.short: Mark the beginning of an update batch.

descr.p: BeginUpdate increases the update count by one. It is advisable to call BeginUpdate before lengthy operations on the stringlist. At the end of these operation, should be called to mark the end of the operation. Descendent classes may use this information to perform optmizations. e.g. updating the screen only once after many strings were added to the list.

All TStrings methods that modify the string list call BeginUpdate before the actual operation, and call endUpdate when the operation is finished. Descendent classes should also call these methods when modifying the string list.

remark.p: Always put the corresponding call to in the context of a Finally block, to ensure that the update count is always descreased at the end of the operation, even if an exception occurred:

element.name: TStrings.Clear
element.short: Removes all strings and associated objects from the list.

descr.p: Clear will remove all strings and their associated objects from the list. After a call to clear, is zero.
Since it is an abstract method, TStrings itself does not implement Clear. Descendent classes such as implement this method.

element.name: TStrings.Delete
element.short: Delete a string from the list.

descr.p: Delete deletes the string at position Index from the list. The associated object is also removed from the list, but not destroyed. Index is zero-based, and should be in the range 0 to Count-1.
Since it is an abstract method, TStrings itself does not implement Delete. Descendent classes such as implement this method.

element.errors: If Index is not in the allowed range, an is raised.

element.name: TStrings.EndUpdate
element.short: Mark the end of an update batch.

descr.p: EndUpdate should be called at the end of a lengthy operation on the stringlist, but only if there was a call to BeginUpdate before the operation was started. It is best to put the call to EndUpdate in the context of a Finally block, so it will be called even if an exception occurs.
For more information, see .

element.name: TStrings.Equals
element.short: Compares the contents of two stringlists.

descr.p: Equals compares the contents of the stringlist with the contents of TheStrings. If the contents match, i.e. the stringlist contain an equal amount of strings, and all strings match, then True is returned. If the number of strings in the lists is is unequal, or they contain one or more different strings, False is returned.

ol.li: The strings are compared case-insensitively.
The associated objects are not compared

element.name: TStrings.Exchange
element.short: Exchanges two strings in the list.

descr.p: Exchange exchanges the strings at positions Index1 and Index2. The associated objects are also exchanged.
Both indexes must be in the range of valid indexes, i.e. must have a value between 0 and Count-1.

element.errors: If either Index1 or Index2 is not in the range of valid indexes, an exception is raised.

element.name: TStrings.GetText
element.short: Returns the contents as a PChar

descr.p: GetText allocates a memory buffer and compies the contents of the stringlist to this buffer as a series of strings, separated by an end-of-line marker. The buffer is zero terminated.
descr.remark: The caller is responsible for freeing the returned memory buffer.

element.name: TStrings.IndexOf
element.short: Find a string in the list and return its position.

descr.p: IndexOf searches the list for S. The search is case-insensitive. If a matching entry is found, its position is returned. if no matching string is found, -1 is returned.

ol.li: Only the first occurrence of the string is returned.
The returned position is zero-based, i.e. 0 indicates the first string in the list.

element.name: TStrings.IndexOfName
element.short: Finds the index of a name in the name-value pairs.

descr.p: IndexOfName searches in the list of strings for a name-value pair with name part Name. If such a pair is found, it returns the index of the pair in the stringlist. If no such pair is found, the function returns -1. The search is done case-insensitive.

ol.li: Only the first occurrence of a matching name-value pair is returned.
The returned position is zero-based, i.e. 0 indicates the first string in the list.

element.name: TStrings.IndexOfObject
element.short: Finds an object in the list and returns its index.

descr.p: IndexOfObject searchs through the list of strings till it find a string associated with AObject, and returns the index of this string. If no such string is found, -1 is returned.

ol.li: Only the first occurrence of a string with associated object AObject is returned; if more strings in the list can be associated with AObject, they will not be found by this routine.
The returned position is zero-based, i.e. 0 indicates the first string in the list.

element.name: TStrings.Insert
element.short: Insert a string in the list.

descr.p: Insert inserts the string S at position Index in the list. Index is a zero-based position, and can have values from 0 to Count. If Index equals Count then the string is appended to the list.

ol.li: All methods that add strings to the list use Insert to add a string to the list.
If the string has an associated object, use instead.

element.errors: If Index is less than zero or larger than Count then an exception is raised.

element.name: TStrings.InsertObject
element.short: Insert a string and associated object in the list.

descr.p: InsertObject inserts the string S and its associated objectAObject at position Index in the list. Index is a zero-based position, and can have values from 0 to Count. If Index equals Count then the string is appended to the list.

element.errors: If Index is less than zero or larger than Count then an exception is raised.

element.name: TStrings.LoadFromFile
element.short: Load the contents of a file as a series of strings.

descr.p: LoadFromFile loads the contents of a file into the stringlist. Each line in the file (as marked by the end-of-line marker of the particular OS the application runs on) becomes one string in the stringlist. This action replaces the contents of the stringlist, it does not append the strings to the current content.
LoadFromFile simply creates a file stream with the given filename, and then executes ; after that the file stream object is destroyed again.

element.name: TStrings.LoadFromStream
element.short: Load the contents of a stream as a series of strings.
element.descr: LoadFromStream loads the contents of Stream into the stringlist. Each line in the stream (as marked by the end-of-line marker of the particular OS the application runs on) becomes one string in the stringlist. This action replaces the contents of the stringlist, it does not append the strings to the current content.

element.name: TStrings.Move
element.short: Move a string from one place in the list to another.

descr.p: Move moves the string at position CurIndex so it has position NewIndex after the move operation. The object associated to the string is also moved. CurIndex and NewIndex should be in the range of 0 to Count-1.

remark.p: NewIndex is not the position in the stringlist before the move operation starts. The move operation

ol.li: removes the string from position CurIndex
inserts the string at position NewIndex

remark.p: This may not lead to the desired result if NewIndex is bigger than CurIndex. Consider the following example:
After the Move operation has completed, 'String 1' will be between 'String 3' and 'String 4'.

element.errors: If either CurIndex or NewIndex is outside the allowed range, an is raised.

element.name: TStrings.SaveToFile
element.short: Save the contents of the list to a file.

descr.p: SaveToFile saves the contents of the stringlist to the file with name FileName. It writes the strings to the file, separated by end-of-line markers, so each line in the file will contain 1 string from the stringlist.
SaveToFile creates a file stream with name FileName, calls and then destroys the file stream object.

element.errors: An exception can be raised if the file FileName cannot be opened, or if it cannot be written to.

element.name: TStrings.SaveToStream
element.short: Save the contents of the string to a stream.

descr.p: SaveToStream saves the contents of the stringlist to Stream. It writes the strings to the stream, separated by end-of-line markers, so each 'line' in the stream will contain 1 string from the stringlist.

element.errors: An exception can be raised if the stream cannot be written to.

element.name: TStrings.SetText
element.short: Set the contents of the list from a PChar.
element.descr: SetText parses the contents of TheText and fills the stringlist based on the contents. It regards TheText as a series of strings, separated by end-of-line markers. Each of these strings is added to the stringlist.

element.name: TStrings.Capacity
element.short: Capacity of the list, i.e. number of strings that the list can currently hold before it tries to expand.

descr.p: Capacity is the number of strings that the list can hold before it tries to allocate more memory.
TStrings returns when read. Trying to set the capacity has no effect. Descendent classes such as can override this property such that it actually sets the new capacity.

element.name: TStrings.GetNameValue
element.short: Return both name and value of a name,value pair based on it's index.

element.name: TStrings.Delimiter
element.short: Delimiter character used in DelimitedText.

element.name: TStrings.DelimitedText
element.short: Get or set all strings in the list in a delimited form.

element.name: TStrings.QuoteChar
element.short: Quote character used in DelimitedText.

element.name: TStrings.NameValueSeparator
element.short: Value of the character used to separate name,value pairs

element.name: TStrings.ValueFromIndex
element.descr: Return the value part of a string based on it's index.

element.name: TStringList.CaseSensitive
element.descr: Indicates whether locating strings happens in a case sensitive manner.

element.name: TStrings.CommaText
element.short: Contents of the list as a comma-separated string.

descr.p: CommaText represents the stringlist as a single string, consisting of a comma-separated concatenation of the strings in the list. If one of the strings contains spaces, comma's or quotes it will be enclosed by double quotes. Any double quotes in a string will be doubled. For instance the following strings:
is converted to

Conversely, when setting the CommaText property, the text will be parsed according to the rules outlined above, and the strings will be set accordingly. Note that spaces will in this context be regarded as string separators, unless the string as a whole is contained in double quotes. Spaces that occur next to a delimiter will be ignored. The following string:
Will be converted to
This is a special case of the property where the quote character is always the double quote, and the delimiter is always the colon.

element.name: TStrings.Count
element.short: Number of strings in the list.

descr.p: Count is the current number of strings in the list. TStrings does not implement this property; descendent classes should override the property read handler to return the correct value.

Strings in the list are always uniquely identified by their Index; the index of a string is zero-based, i.e. it's supported range is 0 to Count-1. trying to access a string with an index larger than or equal to Count will result in an error. Code that iterates over the list in a stringlist should always take into account the zero-based character of the list index.

element.name: TStrings.Names
element.short: Name parts of the name-value pairs in the list.

descr.p: Names provides indexed access to the names of teh name-value pairs in the list. It returns the name part of the Index-th string in the list.
descr.remark: The index is not an index based on the number of name-value pairs in the list. It is the name part of the name-value pair a string Index in the list. If the string at position Index is not a name-value pair (i.e. does not contain the equal sign (=)), then an empty name is returned.

element.name: TStrings.Objects
element.short: Indexed access to the objects associated with the strings in the list.

descr.p: Objects provides indexed access to the objects associated to the strings in the list. Index is a zero-based index and must be in the range of 0 to Count-1.
Setting the objects property will not free the previously associated object, if there was one. The caller is repsonsible for freeing the object that was previously associated to the string.

TStrings does not implement any storage for objects. Reading the Objects property will always return Nil, Setting the property will have no effect. It is the responsability of the descendent classes to provide storage for the associated objects.

element.errors: If an Index outside the valid range is specified, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TStrings.Values
element.short: Value parts of the name-value pairs in the list.

descr.p: Values represents the value parts of the name-value pairs in the list.

When reading this property, if there is a name-value pair in the list of strings that has name part Name, then the corresponding value is returned. If there is no such pair, an empty string is returned.

When writing this value, first it is checked whether there exists a name-value pair in the list with name Name. If such a pair is found, it's value part is overwritten with the specified value. If no such pair is found, a new name-value pair is added with the specified Name and value.

ol.li: Names are compared case-insensitively.
Any character, including whitespace, up till the first equal (=) sign in a string is considered part of the name.

element.name: TStrings.Strings
element.short: Indexed access to teh strings in the list.

descr.p: Strings is the default property of TStrings. It provides indexed read-write access to the list of strings. Reading it will return the string at position Index in the list. Writing it will set the string at position Index.

Index is the position of the string in the list. It is zero-based, i.e. valued values range from 0 (the first string in the list) till Count-1 (the last string in the list). When browsing through the strings in the list, this fact must be taken into account.

To access the objects associated with the strings in the list, use the property. The name parts of name-value pairs can be accessed with the property, and the values can be set or read through the property.
Searching through the list can be done using the method.

element.errors: If Index is outside the allowed range, an exception is raised.

element.name: TStrings.Text
element.short: Contents of the list as one big string.

descr.p: Text returns, when read, the contents of the stringlist as one big string consisting of all strings in the list, separated by an end-of-line marker. When this property is set, the string will be cut into smaller strings, based on the positions of end-of-line markers in the string. Any previous content of the stringlist will be lost.
descr.remark: If any of the strings in the list contains an end-of-line marker, then the resulting string will appear to contain more strings than actually present in the list. To avoid this ambiguity, use the property instead.

element.name: TStrings.StringsAdapter
element.short: Not implemented in Free Pascal.

element.name: TDuplicates
element.short: Type to describe what to do with duplicate values in a .

element.name: TDuplicates.dupIgnore
element.short: Duplicate values will not be be added to the list, but no error will be triggered.

element.name: TDuplicates.dupAccept
element.short: Duplicate values can be added to the list.

element.name: TDuplicates.dupError
element.short: If an attempt is made to add a duplicate value to the list, an exception is raised.

element.name: TStringItemList
element.short: Array of records.
element.descr: This declaration is provided for Delphi compatibility, it is not used in Free Pascal.

element.name: TStringList
element.short: Standard implementation of the class.

descr.p: TStringList is a descendent class of that implements all of the abstract methods introduced there. It also introduces some additional methods:

ul.li: Sort the list, or keep the list sorted at all times
Special handling of duplicates in sorted lists
Notification of changes in the list

element.name: TStringList.Changed
element.short: Called when the list of strings was modified.

element.name: TStringList.Changing
element.short: Called when the list is changing.

element.name: TStringList.Get
element.short: Overrides the standard read handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.GetCapacity
element.short: Overrides the standard read handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.GetCount
element.short: Overrides the standard read handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.GetObject
element.short: Overrides the standard read handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.Put
element.short: Overrides the standard write handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.PutObject
element.short: Overrides the standard write handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.SetCapacity
element.short: Overrides the standard write handler for the property.

element.name: TStringList.SetUpdateState
element.short: Overrides the standard call.

element.name: TStringList.Destroy
element.short: Destroys the stringlist.

descr.p: Destroy clears the stringlist, release all memory allocated for the storage of the strings, and then calls the inherited destroy method.
descr.remark: Any objects associated to strings in the list will not be destroyed; it is the responsability of the caller to destroy all objects associated with strings in the list.

element.name: TStringList.Add
element.short: Implements the function.

descr.p: Add will add S to the list. If the list is sorted and the string S is already present in the list and is dupError then an exception is raised. If Duplicates is set to dupIgnore then the return value is underfined.
If the list is sorted, new strings will not necessarily be added to the end of the list, rather they will be inserted at their alphabetical position.

element.errors: If the list is sorted and the string S is already present in the list and is dupError then an exception is raised.

element.name: TStringList.Clear
element.short: Implements the function.

element.name: TStringList.Delete
element.short: Implements the function.

element.name: TStringList.Exchange
element.short: Implements the function.

descr.p: Exchange will exchange two items in the list as described in .

element.name: TStringList.Find
element.short: Locates the index for a given string in sorted lists.

descr.p: Find returns True if the string S is present in the list. Upon exit, the Index parameter will contain the position of the string in the list. If the string is not found, the function will return False and Index will contain the position where the string will be inserted if it is added to the list.

ol.li: Use this method only on sorted lists. For unsorted lists, use instead.
Find uses a binary search method to locate the string

element.name: TStringList.IndexOf
element.short: Overrides the property.
element.descr: IndexOf overrides the ancestor method . It tries to optimize the search by executing a binary search if the list is sorted. The function returns the position of S if it is found in the list, or -1 if the string is not found in the list.

element.name: TStringList.Insert
element.short: Overrides the method.
element.descr: Insert will insert the string S at position Index in the list. If the list is sorted, an exception will be raised instead. Index is a zero-based position.
element.errors: If Index contains an invalid value (less than zero or larger than Count, or the list is sorted, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TStringList.Sort
element.short: Sorts the strings in the list.
element.descr: Sort will sort the strings in the list using the quicksort algorithm. If the list has its property set to True then nothing will be done.

element.name: TStringList.Duplicates
element.short: Describes the behaviour of a sorted list with respect to duplicate strings.

descr.p: Duplicates describes what to do in case a duplicate value is added to the list:
If the stringlist is not sorted, the Duplicates setting is ignored.

element.name: TStringList.Sorted
element.short: Determines whether the list is sorted or not.

descr.p: Sorted can be set to True in order to cause the list of strings to be sorted. Further additions to the list will be inserted at the correct position so the list remains sorted at all times. Setting the property to False has no immediate effect, but will allow strings to be inserted at any position.

ol.li: When Sorted is True, cannot be used. For sorted lists, should be used instead.
If Sorted is True, the setting has effect. This setting is ignored when Sorted is False.

element.name: TStringList.OnChange
element.short: Event triggered after the list was modified.

descr.p: OnChange can be assigned to respond to changes that have occurred in the list. The handler is called whenever strings are added, moved, modified or deleted from the list.
The Onchange event is triggered after the modification took place. When the modification is about to happen, an event occurs.

element.name: TStringList.OnChanging
element.short: Event triggered when the list is about to be modified.

descr.p: OnChanging can be assigned to respond to changes that will occurred in the list. The handler is called whenever strings will be added, moved, modified or deleted from the list.
The Onchanging event is triggered before the modification will take place. When the modification has happened, an event occurs.

element.name: TStream
element.short: Base class for streams.

descr.p: TStream is the base class for all streaming classes. It defines abstract methods for reading, writing from and to streams, as well as functions to determine the size of the stream as well as the current position of the stream.
Descendent classes such as or then implement these abstract methods to write streams to memory or file.

element.name: TStream.SetSize
element.short: Sets the size of the stream
element.descr: SetSize is the write handler for the property. The TStream implementation of SetSize does nothing, but descendent classes may override this methods to allow programmers to set the size of the stream.

element.name: TStream.Read
element.short: Reads data from the stream to a buffer and returns the number of bytes read.

descr.p: Read attempts to read Count from the stream to Buffer and returns the number of bytes actually read.
This method should be used when the number of bytes is not determined. If a specific number of bytes is expected, use instead.
Read is an abstract method that is overridden by descendent classes to do the actual reading.

element.errors: Descendent classes that do not allow reading from the stream may raise an exception when the Read is used.

element.name: TStream.Write
element.short: Writes data from a buffer to the stream and returns the number of bytes written.

descr.p: Write attempts to write Count bytes from Buffer to the stream. It returns the actual number of bytes written to the stream.
This method should be used when the number of bytes that should be written is not determined. If a specific number of bytes should be written, use instead.
Write is an abstract method that is overridden by descendent classes to do the actual writinging.

element.errors: Descendent classes that do not allow writing to the stream may raise an exception when Write is used.

element.name: TStream.Seek
element.short: Sets the current position in the stream

descr.p: Seek sets the position of the stream to Offset bytes from Origin. Origin can have one of the following values:

tr.td: Set the position relative to the start of the stream.
Set the position relative to the beginning of the stream.
Set the position relative to the end of the stream.

descr.p: Offset should be negative when the origin is SoFromEnd. It should be positive for soFromBeginning and can have both signs for soFromCurrent
This is an abstract method, which must be overridden by descendent classes. They may choose not to implement this method for all values of Origin and Offset.

element.errors: An exception may be raised if this method is called with an invalid pair of Offset,Origin values. e.g. a negative offset for soFromBeginning.

element.name: TStream.ReadBuffer
element.short: Reads data from the stream to a buffer

descr.p: ReadBuffer reads Count bytes of the stream into Buffer. If the stream does not contain Count bytes, then an exception is raised.

ReadBuffer should be used to read in a fixed number of bytes, such as when reading structures or the content of variables. If the number of bytes is not determined, use instead. ReadBuffer uses Read internally to do the actual reading.

element.errors: If the stream does not allow to read Count bytes, then an exception is raised.

element.name: TStream.WriteBuffer
element.short: Writes data from the stream to the buffer

descr.p: WriteBuffer writes Count bytes to the stream from Buffer. If the stream does not allow Count bytes to be written, then an exception is raised.

WriteBuffer should be used to read in a fixed number of bytes, such as when writing structures or the content of variables. If the number of bytes is not determined, use instead. WriteBuffer uses Write internally to do the actual reading.

element.errors: If the stream does not allow to write Count bytes, then an exception is raised.

element.name: TStream.CopyFrom
element.short: Copy data from one stream to another

descr.p: CopyFrom reads Count bytes from Source and writes them to the current stream. This updates the current position in the stream. After the action is completed, the number of bytes copied is returned.
This can be used to quickly copy data from one stream to another or to copy the whole contents of the stream.

element.name: TStream.ReadComponent
element.short: Reads component data from a stream

descr.p: ReadComponent reads a component state from the stream and transfers this state to Instance. If Instance is nil, then it is created first based on the type stored in the stream. ReadComponent returns the component as it is read from the stream.
ReadComponent simply creates a object and calls its ReadRootComponent method.

element.errors: If an error occurs during the reading of the component, an exception is raised.

element.name: TStream.ReadComponentRes
element.short: Reads component data and resource header from a stream

descr.p: ReadComponentRes reads a resource header from the stream, and then calls ReadComponent to read the component state from the stream into Instance.

This method is usually called by the global streaming method when instantiating forms and datamodules as created by an IDE. It should be used mainly on Windows, to store components in Windows resources.

element.errors: If an error occurs during the reading of the component, an exception is raised.

element.name: TStream.WriteComponent
element.short: Write component data to the stream

descr.p: WriteComponent writes the published properties of Instance to the stream, so they can later be read with . This method is intended to be used by an IDE, to preserve the state of a form or datamodule as designed in the IDE.
WriteComponent simply calls WriteDescendent with Nil ancestor.

element.name: TStream.WriteComponentRes
element.short: Write resource header and component data to a stream

descr.p: WriteComponentRes writes a ResName resource header to the stream and then calls WriteComponent to write the published properties of Instance to the stream.
This method is intened for use by an IDE that can use it to store forms or datamodules as designed in a Windows resource stream.

element.name: TStream.WriteDescendent
element.short: Write component data to a stream, relative to an ancestor

descr.p: WriteDescendent writes the state of Instance to the stream where it differs from Ancestor, i.e. only the changed properties are written to the stream.
WriteDescendent creates a object and calls its WriteDescendent object. The writer is passed a binary driver object by default.

element.name: TStream.WriteDescendentRes
element.short: Write resource header and component data to a stream, relative to an ancestor

descr.p: WriteDescendentRes writes a ResName resource header, and then calls WriteDescendent to write the state of Instance to the stream where it differs from Ancestor, i.e. only the changed properties are written to the stream.
This method is intened for use by an IDE that can use it to store forms or datamodules as designed in a Windows resource stream.

element.name: TStream.WriteResourceHeader
element.short: Write resource header to the stream

descr.p: WriteResourceHeader writes a resource-file header for a resource called ResName. It returns in FixupInfo the argument that should be passed on to .

WriteResourceHeader should not be used directly. It is called by the and
methods.

element.name: TStream.FixupResourceHeader
element.short: Not implemented in FPC

descr.p: FixupResourceHeader is used to write the size of the resource after a component was written to stream. The size is determined from the current position, and it is written at position FixupInfo. After that the current position is restored.
FixupResourceHeader should never be called directly; it is handled by the streaming system.

element.name: TStream.ReadResHeader
element.short: Read a resource header from the stream.

descr.p: ReadResourceHeader reads a reasource file header from the stream. It positions the stream just beyond the header.
ReadResourceHeader should not be called directly, it is called by the streaming system when needed.

element.errors: If the resource header is invalid an exception is raised.

element.name: TStream.ReadByte
element.short: Read a byte from the stream and return its value.
element.descr: ReadByte reads one byte from the stream and returns its value.
element.errors: If the byte cannot be read, a exception will be raised. This is a utility function which symply calls the Read function.

element.name: TStream.ReadWord
element.short: Read a word from the stream and return its value.
element.descr: ReadWord reads one Word (i.e. 2 bytes) from the stream and returns its value. This is a utility function which symply calls the Read function.
element.errors: If the word cannot be read, a exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.ReadDWord
element.short: Read a DWord from the stream and return its value.
element.descr: ReadDWord reads one DWord (i.e. 4 bytes) from the stream and returns its value. This is a utility function which simply calls the Read function.
element.errors: If the DWord cannot be read, a exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.ReadAnsiString
element.short: Read an ansistring from the stream and return its value.
element.descr:
ReadAnsiString reads an ansistring from the stream and returns its value. This is a utility function which simply calls the read function several times.
The Ansistring should be stored as 4 bytes (a DWord) representing the length of the string, and then the string value itself. The WriteAnsiString function writes an ansistring in such a format.
element.errors: If the AnsiString cannot be read, a exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.WriteByte
element.short: Write a byte to the stream.
element.descr:
WriteByte writes the byte B to the stream. This is a utility function which simply calls the Write function.
The byte can be read from the stream using the ReadByte function.
element.errors: If an error occurs when attempting to write, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.WriteWord
element.short: Write a word to the stream.
element.descr:
WriteWord writes the word W (i.e. 2 bytes) to the stream. This is a utility function which simply calls the Write function.
The word can be read from the stream using the ReadWord function.
element.errors: If an error occurs when attempting to write, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.WriteDWord
element.short: Write a DWord to the stream.
element.descr:
WriteDWord writes the DWord D (i.e. 4 bytes) to the stream. This is a utility function which simply calls the Write function.
The DWord can be read from the stream using the ReadDWord function.
element.errors: If an error occurs when attempting to write, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.WriteAnsiString
element.short: Write an ansistring to the stream.
element.descr:
WriteAnsiString writes the AnsiString S (i.e. 4 bytes) to the stream. This is a utility function which simply calls the Write function.
The ansistring is written as a 4 byte length specifier, followed by the ansistring's content.
The ansistring can be read from the stream using the ReadAnsiString function.
element.errors: If an error occurs when attempting to write, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TStream.Position
element.short: The current position in the stream.

descr.p: Position can be read to determine the current position in the stream. It can be written to to set the (absolute) position in the stream. The position is zero-based, so to set the position at the beginning of the stream, the position must be set to zero.
descr.remark: Not all TStream descendants support setting the position in the stream, so this should be used with care.

element.errors: Some descendents may raise an exception if they do not support setting the stream position.

element.name: TStream.Size
element.short: The current size of the stream.

descr.p: Size can be read to determine the stream size or to set the stream size.
descr.remark: Not all descendents of TStream support getting or setting the stream size; they may raise an exception if the Size property is read or set.

element.name: THandleStream
element.short: Base clas for streams that are identified by an OS handle.

descr.p: THandleStream is an abstract descendent of the class that provides methods for a stream to handle all reading and writing to and from a handle, provided by the underlying OS. To this end, it overrides the Read and Write methods of TStream.

ul.li: ThandleStream does not obtain a handle from the OS by itself, it just handles reading and writing to such a handle by wrapping the system calls for reading and writing; Descendent classes should obtain a handle from the OS by themselves and pass it on in the inherited constructor.
Contrary to Delphi, no seek is implemented for THandleStream, since pipes and sockets do not support this. The seek is implemented in descendent methods that support it.

element.name: THandleStream.Create
element.short: Create a handlestream from an OS Handle.
element.descr: Create creates a new instance of a THandleStream class. It stores AHandle in an internal variable and then calls the inherited constructor.

element.name: THandleStream.Read
element.short: Overrides standard read method.

descr.p: Read implements the abstract Read method of TStream. It uses the Handle property to read the Count bytes into Buffer
If no error occurs while reading, the number of bytes actually read will be returned.

element.errors: If the operating system reports an error while reading from the handle, -1 is returned.

element.errors: If the operating system reports an error while writing to handle, -1 is returned.

element.name: THandleStream.Handle
element.short: The OS handle of the stream.
